text: Following the practice set out by the existing OAuth1 client, this new Client class supports all the bearer types as well as MAC authentication. I don't know of any providers that use MAC, so I can't test whether it works properly, but it defers to the existing MAC methods. This doesn't include anything for the Server class; it's just a convenient wrapper for things like requests to work with.

text:
Hey @gulopine and thanks for the pull request!

It would be great if adding OAuth 2 was this simple but unfortunately it is not. OAuth 2 differs significantly from OAuth 1, ie. no signing of request, no signature types or methods. Instead the burden of security responsibility is largely dumped onto SSL making room for a plethora of client profiles, authorization flows and token types. Therefore, rather than enjoying getting some nice crypto work done correctly as with OAuth1 the focus has shifted to designing an appealing and extensible interface, since under the hood there is not that much work to be done by OAuth 2 clients. 

Your pull request booted me into starting a discussion on the topic, feel free to join in =) #44

Yeah, I wasn't sure how much of the OAuth 1 client to copy, since the goals are so much different. I played around with a couple other approaches to it as well, so I'll be interested to take part in #44.
Closing this as experimental OAuth 2 client support has now been added. Although there might be quite substantial changes depending on which way the discussions in #44 go.
